We did the cleaning of the chisel, placing the pipes on a piece of back plank and having a lack of communication, I found myself with my finger between the pipe and the plank while my teammate pushed it, which Result of an injury to the left ring finger.

4283 Leeboy grader, Was reported to the mechanics that the blade would not swing. Randy Greenfield inspected the machine and found the big nut on the inside of the cylinder had pulled off the threads. He was able to pull the rod straight out of the cylinder body. He removed the cylinder to prep to ship out.Later that day another mechanic reported that there was evidence of blade contact with the rib all the way down the main line. Fresh marks on the hard bottom near the rib, and some rib contact marks, accompanied by grader tire tread marks in the freshly graded road.

While conducting a backwash at 002 the backwash effluent tank overfilled and water ran out the main door to water treatment plant 002.  Tony found that the VFD for the backwash effluent pump had faulted out which caused the tank to overfill.  He was able to reset the VFD and get the pump running.  The pump lowered the level in the tank and stopped overflowing.  Approximately 1000 gallons of water went out the door but was contained to the large event pond outside of the water plant.

*While bringing the filter room on line my operator noticed that he was not getting any alcohol to his Pb drum. Operator had attempted to prime the line to discharge but was still unable to get flow. Operator called supervision for assistance. *Got with the operator to inspect the discharge end of the line at the Pb drum and asked him to watch it while I double checked the pumps and valving.*Once at the alcohol pumps I noticed that several of the lines and the way they were running through the Masterflex pumps had been swapped around. When my operator had started both pumps that would normally be used and already set up to get alcohol to the drums, he failed to notice this issue. *The Pb Masterflex pump was currently set up with both the Pb and Zn alcohol lines running through it, but only the inside head of the Pb pump was closed and locked allowing alcohol to make it to the Zn side but not the Pb. *Noticed the Pennol had been set up to run through the Zn side Masterflex pump. When my operator had previously started the Zn side pump the line ended up being dead headed and came off at the nipple and was being pumped into the containment behind the totes closest to the boiler room wall.

Cord and myself were attempting to move the Geho A discharge to spigots A11S and A12S.  When we got flow to A12S we found a leak where the spigot line meets the main line.  We then attempted to move to A9S and A10S.  We closed the knife gate on the main line after A10S but noticed that we continued to have flow leaking by the knife gate to the end of the line.  We then attempted to swap to A7S and A8S and again saw flow at the end of the line after closing knife gate after A8S. Finally, we returned the discharge to A3S and A4S and closed the knife gate after A4S.

By picking up a palletÖ the height of the last rocking the forks came out of the 6 feet at the end of the pallet. They broke through the walls. The pallets hung on the computer screen in the surrounding offices.

There were two rounds missed today.  One in 19 Stope in the 90 Vein East, and one in 21 Stope East.
Our Crew attended the Covid informational meeting today from 7:30 - 9:00 PM.  Due to the extra time from the meeting this morning it may have cost us these rounds.

I was called down to the 6500 ESS by Tacy Pearce to look at the damage to the louvers and the roll up door on the ESS caused by the blasting of 52 Ramp Development heading. The concusion had sucked the roll up door out of the track, and bent the louvers. This will be an ongoing issue with the blasting that needs to be done to establish 52 Ramp.
Lost rounds in 19 and 21 do to having to give there 2yd. to other priority headings. We also had two of the 2yds down for 4hrs each last night.

The event arrived at the dump on the way to the pit. around 2 a.m. I felt a little pain, tried some medication and took a break but my pain did not decrease. At the start of the shift I already had a pain of 4/10. I took medication and endured the pain until it was unbearable.
Tasha was transferring alcohol and when she went to hook up the air to the ARO pump the pump kicked the transfer hose out of the tote resulting in alcohol getting on Tasha's clothes.

Chris and I went out to the seeps with the electricians to test the floats for the secondary pump to make sure the floats were working properly. While testing the floats we discovered the secondary pump itself was not operating properly resulting in the level not being dropped enough to activate the low level float to shut off the pump.
While walking through the load out building I noticed that someone had placed a full 5 gallon gas can on top of the flammable cabinet instead of inside the cabinet.

I was called down to the 6500 ESS by Tacy Pearce to look at the damage to the louvers and the roll up door on the ESS caused by the blasting of 52 Ramp Development heading. While working on cleaning up the mess next to BC-9 Tasha had the Standard crusher stick, she was able to get everything stopped without burying the standard too bad. Billie and I were able to get it dug out and backed off fairly easy and had everything going again in less than an hour.

While operating the crusher Tasha had a flat rock come through and get stuck between the rails on BC-7 between the Jaw and Standard discharge causing the muck to back up into the Jaw and overload BC-7.  After we were able to get the flat rock removed and dug out under the jaw we were able to jog BC-7 ahead enough to restart the crusher and crush out the circulating load before she started crushing out of the Coarse ore bins again.

Tasha noticed a large chunk of skirting starting to tear off on the west side of the tail end of BC-9. Tasha and Anthony cut off the chunk of skirting so it wouldn't finish tearing off while she was running and potentially plug a chute. Thank you Tasha for catching it before it became an issue.

While conducting a site walk through with the environmental department and Idaho DEQ a small flow of water was observed discharging from a pipe directly above the 003 outfall. At the time I closed the ball valve on the line so no more water discharging.  After the inspection was concluded myself and Craig Shiner went back to determine what course of action should be done.  We along with Silas Walls determined to run a hose off the line to the seeps collection box.

We were trying to pour sand to U/G, started having communication errors in the system,the mixer doors would not open.  I was called over to investigate problem.  I went to the second floor and saw material coming out the upper doors of the mix hopper.  Below the Mix hopper was empty, ran up to the Sand and Pebble hopper and it had at least 3 batches in it, had to open doors manually to get it to drop out.  After that the doors would not communicate, the limit switches were not working properly.  A flush was already sent to U/G so we had to drop material to the floor.  When the batches dropped it shot out the sample doors.  Large messes on bottom two levels.  The cement chute also plugged off from the bottom shroud up to the rubber sleeve.  It was very hard towards the bottom, may have been plugging off over time and contributed to the issue.

Martin was trying to open the dump valve on the bottom floor of paste plant to dump batch to the floor when batch over ran the upper floor and showered down on Martin.  He was able to get out of the way for the most part but he did get a little material on him

While operating the grind circuit Chris lost feed from the Fine Ore Bin, Billie and I went to try and get the feeder reset with no promising results. I called for electricians to come up from underground and shortly after called out Maintenance so that we had full coverage to diagnose and fix the problem. The electricians discovered that the cooling fan for the VFD had burnt up and overheated causing a fuse to blow.

While Anthony was doing his pre-shift at 003 he discovered that the secondary seeps pump breaker was kicked out and would not be operational if the primary were to fail. Anthony immediately reset the breaker and the pump kicked on even though the water level was below the low level floats. I consulted with Chris Stoddard and discovered early today that the secondary pump had stayed on and sucked the seeps dry instead of shutting off at the proper level. Anthony shut the pump off and put it back in auto so it is currently operational if the primary fails you will just have to make sure the secondary doesn't stay running.

While Sam was shutting down the filter room and cleaning the Vats he discovered that one of the rakes were broken on the large drum Vat. Zach was already here from the fine ore feeder issue and we inspected the damage together so maintenance is already informed.
While shifting the ore ship forward, it was alongside the fender and the ships handrail came alongside dolphin #1 and broke a weld and bent up a metal strap joining the railings.

Byron asked for Communication Standard to be updated since the Mine Department is using channel #3 not the assigned channel #2 on the leaky feeder system. This was due to problems with channel #2 several months ago and everyone since has been using channel #3. On Communication Standard LF-HSE-042 it has 2-shaft assigned channel #1, 4-shaft assigned #6 and Silver Shaft assigned channel #5. After talking to hoist operator, I learned 2-shaft is using channel #6, 4-shaft is using channel #4 and Silver Shaft is using channel #5.   3 out of 4 assigned radio frequencies area  not being used as documented.

EE durasoiled heading down the 56 vent drift.  He turned around at the bottom and started heading back up to the 6500 lateral.  Made it up about 150' and the tractor started sliding backwards.  The trailer went into the rib.  Tom tried to pull forward to straighten out and back down the ramp in a controlled manner, but the tractor could not get traction in 2wd.  Tom tried to shift into 4wd but the 4 wd drive wouldn't engage.  A 2 yard was located and used to pull the tractor straight and to slowly back it down the ramp. EE entered the security check in for COVID at approximately 0530.  When ashed if he has been in contact with anyone with COVID19 or experiencing any unusual symptoms his response was "I don't know."  Security reminded him the process was necessary for him to enter his workplace and he responded with "I have not agreed with this process since it started."  Security informed him that his agreement was not necessary but he needed to answer the questions or he would be sent home. He said he wanted to work but he did not give an answer other than I don't know and drove way from the checkpoint before the issue could be resolved.  There have been similar incidents with the individual in the past but this is the first time a refusal to answer has happened.

Brian walked through the reagent room and saw the copper leaking from the recirc line. He turned off the recirc pump and called Mark Miller who had the bull gang guys pump the sump into a rinsed tote.  Notified metallurgist.

While doing a routine check at Pond 4, Jordan went in the vault house and found that the sprinkler pump was not running and the overflow of the pump box was running into the decant line.  Jordan called the water treatment supervisor about what was going on.  I let Jordan know that when he had the power bump earlier the pump lost power and must need restarted.  Jordan reset the pump and was able to get it started back up.

Jordan noticed on computer in control room that the agitators had kicked out and an alarm for auxiliary failure at 003.  Jordan went to 003 and discovered that a power bump had occurred and the plant was starting to fill with water.  He was able to restart the overflow pump and the transfer pump but unable to get clarifier feed pump to reset.  Jordan was able to gravity flow thru the plant while waiting on an electrician to look at clarifier feed pump.  Electrician was able to get the clarifier feed pump reset and Jordan was able to restart the plant.  Water on the floor of the plant did not go outside the building and only got within a few feet of going out the door.

Operator called me on radio and said basement was filling up with slurry, ran to control room to look at monitors and saw the Ball Mill trash screen coming over. Operator ran to MCC room and reset the breaker and started the trash screen.

Anthony was heading out to pond 4 vault house to increase the decant when he came across a tree that had broke and fell across the road not far before the pond 4 gate. Anthony notified me right away, Billie and I went to spot while Sam brought the 950 to push the tree off to the side of the road so we had safe access to Pond 4.

I (Cliff Shiner) was notified by phone at 4:46am that the hoist was down. Nick told me that the hoist would not clutch in or out. After giving Maintenance some time to get it going, with no success I called MSHA at 5:12am. The Denver office called me back at 5:32am to get more information. I told them that we had 27 people underground and that we were going to bring them up our secondary escape way (2 Shaft). At 8:56am i called them back to let them know that everyone was out of the mine. At 9:31 I called  them again to let them know that the Silver Shaft Hoist was back up and we were returning to work. Having the hoist down cost us to not blast three rounds that were ready to blast from Night shift. We also missed approximately 2 1/2 hours of work on day shift.

Jason just finished bolting and saw a rock that he wanted to moil off so that it didn't come down on him when loading. The rock cut him just below the knee. Jason went and got his partner to look at his knee and they determined it should get some stitches. We are still having issues with our 6' Jackleg steel. We have had 4, 6' steel shank at the chuck so far this week. All of the stopes have a chuck liner gauge and have been checking their machines. At appx 12:30am Nolan called to the mill and said there was no flow discharging out of the P-23. There was no fire, just some residual smoke from one of the exhaust motor fans. We had to perform an emergency shutdown of the Mill.  Electricians came up from U/G and they said that the vfd fan burned and fried the vfd controls.

Employee was rinsing out an empty bucket which originally contained Sodium Hypochlorite in order to help with sampling in the crusher. On the second rinse, the employee removed the hose from the spout and the liquid came up several feet splashing on the employees clothes. This being the second rinse, the liquid was extremely dilute so there was no cause for alarm. If the bucket had more sodium hypochlorite left in it, or it was the first rinse, or the dilute solution got into eyes rather than simply on clothes this situation could have been worse.

IncidentDescription: Jase took 4250 2yd from the east side of 12 stope to the bottom of the slot to grab his wire and bolting supplies for the day.When he pulled up to the face on the west side to hang his wire, Jase and his helper William Curl could smell electrical burning. They then noticed smoke coming from the starter area on the loader, Jase turned the master switch off on the loader and grabbed a fire extinguisher. By the time he had made it back around the loader to have another look at the starter, the electrical plug on top of the starter motor had started burning. He discharged his fire extinguisher band put the small fire out. Jase called Hammerberg and the mechanics to inform them of the issue. Talking with maintenance, when Jase started the loader the starter stayed engaged to the ring gear and caused the starter to over heat and catch fire.

While training Tasha Auger in the crusher Martin Munoz was doing a routine daily pre-shift and work place exam , around 0600 Martin found that underneath the standard crusher was full of trash and dust backing up into the cone. Martin started removing the trash from under the standard cone, while doing so he found about a 4" piece of stick powder smashed in a PVC pipe. Explosives were put in the lock box immediately and the underground shifter was notified right away, the box was locked and guarded until underground personnel were able to retrieve and take the explosives underground to be properly disposed of. Although handling explosives is never ideal this gave us an opportunity to do hands on training of how to properly handle and dispose of explosives in the crusher, it also gave a new operator in training first hand knowledge of how important it is to clean under the standard crusher every day not only for the purpose of mechanical issues but also safety.

Operator was performing a paste pour.  He called his supervisor when the auto-sequence of batching stopped working.  After examining program we found that no cement was being added so it wasn't dropping the batch to the mixer.  We switched augers with no luck. The pour was paused for approximately 40 minutes during this.

During a pour a bucket of mostly frozen sand was loaded into the emergency hopper. This resulted in multiple problems. First, BC-44 clogged. Aaron cleared the chute but did not notice the ice. Next, when the mixer doors opened the load failed to drop out. As this has been part of an ongoing problem, Aaron let the system cycle thinking it would drop out next batch. It did not so he went into manual and opened the mixer doors. The Mercedes valve immediately plugged. Aaron opened the dump valve, inspected it and noticed the ice. He contacted Mat and let him know about the problem - Josh came to assist and Mat drove to the head frame in case we needed to flush from there. As there was too much ice to get out by hand, Aaron opened the fresh water flush line with the dump valve open to try and push it out. He then put the Mercedes back together and attempted to continue the pour. The Mercedes immediately plugged again. At this point approximately 10 minutes had passed so Aaron attempted to send a flush. Josh opened the Mercedes dump valve and Aaron opened the mixer doors and the Schwing pump dump valve. They both had more frozen chunks of sand and the Schwing pump would not drain. Aaron cleared the plug with a sledge and by hand and then turned on the mix water to push any remaining ice out. They closed both valves and attempted to send a flush. The Schwing pump started and the water turned on but they noticed the discharge pressure was 1-5, too low to be sending water. Aaron went to the second deck, opened the hatch to view the charge hopper and saw that it was filling up and soon started to spill over. More ice must have been plugging the charge hopper just above the Schwing pump discharge. Aaron contacted Mat and informed him he would need to send a flush from the head frame. Shortly after the ice must have dropped out as the charge hopper level started to come down. The discharge pressure went to 20 and the 5900 level pressure started to rise so they assumed they were successfully sending a flush. They informed Mat he would not need to flush from up top. Around 22 minutes passed between the initial clog and the successful flush. As the pour was nearly complete, 1/2 feet from the top of the wall, underground decided to call the pour there and they shut down.

While performing a routine paste back fill pour, the Schwing pump developed a hydraulic leak to the floor. This oil flowed into a nearby floor sump. The estimated oil spillage was 15 gallons. The sump does not run in AUTO so it did not pump any fluid out of the containment. Oil absorbent materials were deployed as well as the oil and water in the sump was pumped out into a tote. The oil absorbent materials were bagged and label for disposal to Clay. The leak was repaired and tested by Mill Maintenance. Pour was resumed.

Tony went to WTP 003 to complete his 11 pm round.  When he walked inside the plant he saw that the building was filling with water and was almost to the doors.  He called his supervisor immediately.  Supervisor (Chris) and Casey Nelson proceeded to 003 to assist.  Once we got the water under control we began to investigate.  We found that although the pumps were running they were at minimal hz and not keeping up with the flow.  The pumps were non-responsive to the tank levels or manually trying to change the speed.  The decision was made by supervisor to leave the plant down.  Casey went back to the mill and with the help of Martin restored the water balance to what we were running before restarting WTP 003. While they did this, Chris and Tony stayed at 003 and we were able to pump out the main building and the disc filter building.  Seeps was valved directly to pond 3 but was leaking by valve to 003 surge tank.  Opened seeps drain into building and valved floor sump to Pond 3.

On Tuesday, February 2nd 2021, I reported to 5900 Station with Mine shifter Beaver Williams. Once on the station, we found two mining crews along with the loading crew I was supervising all looking for transportation. Beaver and I spent approximately 1 hour driving around looking for Kubota's for use. Beaver and I found one parked at 5370 loading pocket which we had Jason Ohman take to the guys waiting on 5900 station. While we were doing this, one of the loading crew guys found a Kubota and everyone was transported back to their headings. I had to catch a ride from the grader operator who had a Kubota. Due to only having 1 Kubota for all the guys loading in 12 stope a couple of trips had to be made for people and hauling powder and primers.

On Wednesday, February 3, 2021, I had 4 newly hired employees to take on an escapeway tour. Shifter Beaver Williams provided me one of his employee?s, Joe to assist in driving new employee?s around. I had spoken with one of our Boart Drillers about leaving the training department Kubota on station at 5900 for us. Beaver in front of others and myself joked with them saying they could take it and his, knowing I had spoken to them already. Once on 5900, I found Beaver waiting and no other Kubota?s for our use. 2nd day in a row, Beaver and I had to drive around and look for a Kubota and in mean time I was able to radio 12 stope and have them get the training departments Kubota and bring it to 5900 station. Beaver and I found the repair Kubota at 5370 pocket, which we took and 5900 and had it taken to the Boart guys. Without Beaver or I knowing, the Kubota we took was being used by mechanics and by us taking it left them at the pocket with no transportation. While we were at pocket we never seen or hear anyone. This was a huge waste of time again and we did not get started with tour until around 830.

On Tuesday, February 2nd, 2021, I was overseeing an UBB Loadout in 12E. After arriving to stope, we found the stope was not ready for loading. All utilities had to be removed, collar pipe cut off and stemming brought in. Once this had all be done and Emulsion Pump was brought in, we began prepping to load. All the holes were primed and once we started the startup process, we immediately had troubles with pump. After many attempts to figure out what was wrong, I had to telephone Byron and Brandon Collier. Brandon believed it was an issue he had before and would be able to fix it in the morning. This was the first I had heard of any problems before with pump and first Byron had heard anything. Stope was barricaded with signage and left for loading team to try next day shift.

IncidentDescription: On the morning of 2/2/21 of the Zanetti concentrate truck drivers was traveling north of Cusick, Wa, en route to Trail B.C.  His truck encountered black ice which caused him to veer off of the highway.  There was no shoulder on the highway here.  He potentially over corrected causing the truck to turn sideways on the road.  This eventually caused the hitch to break disconnecting the trailer from the truck.  The trailer continued over the bank and stayed upright. Due to the overcorrection the truck rolled one full time and landed on its tires.  The driver was shaken up but okay, he was checked out by EMT's on site and later checked at a hospital and was released.  The lead concentrate completely spilled out of the truck.

The employee went home  after shift and went to bed. He woke up and his scratch was inflamed. The employee tried to dig out dirt with a knife and felt the blade drag against a foreign object. The employee used a magnet over his hand which pulled up his skin. He immediately went to urgent care and had a 4 mm piece of metal removed from hand. He called his supervisor and reported the incident while at urgent care.

A power outage at the 003 water treatment plant occurred.  Operators, Casey Nelson and Tony Houston were able to restart the plant.  During this time Jake Schuff and his bullgang operators were at the plant for the unloading of coag from truck to our storage tank. After Casey and Tony restarted the plant they proceeded to Pond 4 Vaulthouse to check on things.  While they were gone Jake reported that the plant had multiple more power bumps and he was restarting it.  I, Chris Stoddard, proceeded to the plant to assist Jake.  When I get out there the plant was running and I double checked everything.  Jake and his bullgangers left back to 003 to unload the rest of the coag.  The plant continued to run for approximately one half hour.  Casey and Tony had just returned from Pond 4 when the plant lost power again.  We attempted to restart the plant again.  The wonderware system was showing that the pumps were running but none of them actually were.  The plant begin to fill with water as the flow to the clarifier was gravity feeding. We were able to isolate the flow and stop the water from coming into the plant. Silas Walls and Craig Shiner came out the plant after we had it shut down to help.  We found that the main PLC had gone into a fatal error and thats why we couldn't control anything through the wonderware. We were able to get an electrician out there and able to reset the system again giving us control through the wonderware program.

Operator was moving concentrate in loadout with 928G Cat Loader.  While moving lead into bunker #5 and trying to stack it as high as he could the loader lifted on him.  When it lifted the top of the cab made contact with the beam at the top of the bunker.  This caused pressure on top of the cab resulting in a broken windshield.  The damage to the windshield is in the top right corner and doesn't impair the view from operating the vehicle.  The operator notified his supervisor of the incident immediately after it occurred.

Operator was doing an equipment inspection on the 950 loader and raised the hydraulic inspection hatch for the back. He did not notice the cord for the oil block heater being fed through the small door on the side, and while lifting the hatch the cord broke for the block heater.

The crushing plant operator called the supervisor on his radio to report that the dust collector had shut off while he was down and he could not get it to restart.  Supervisor went up to assist him with no luck.  Then two additional employees went to the crushing plant.  They tried everything that they knew to reset it but nothing worked.  Tried to call underground electricians, mine shift supervisor answered pager phone and said he would notify electricians they were trying to get a hold of them. Shortly after an electrician called the mill.  They informed him of what was going on and he said that they would return to the surface to work on the problem.  WO#383406.

Crusher was having issues with belts tripping out, and I was called up to assist in figuring out what and where the issue was. Two employees were pull testing bolts in the back of the 56 Vent Drift/Ramp below 6500L.  They were working on top of the Normet scissors lift and were wearing harnesses and were tied off to the center pin on the work deck.  They had attached the clevis & pull-bar assembly to the rock bolt, as well as the cage and the jack cylinder, and started tightening up the nut on the pull-bar to secure the assembly.  There was still a gap on one side between the rock face and the cage, so we added at least two steel plates (~ dimensions 6" x 6" x 1/4") to fill the gap.  They tightened the assembly further, and everything seemed secure.  They pressured up the jack cylinder and completed the pull test.  When disassembling the equipment, two of the steel plates fell and hit one of the employees on the left forearm and the other plate hit the employees respirator, which was hanging from his neck.

Tom was hauling supplies on 5900 main line with a small Cat telehandler. He did not use the block light and Chris stopped him and asked why he had not used the block light. While returning from Pond 4/003 I received a call from a supervisor that water was going out the door in pumphouse #4 (approximately 25-30 gallons).  I arrived shortly after the call and the water had already stopped leaving the building and was being pumped back into the system through the sump pump. Several employees were already working to figure out what had caused the trash screen to go over so hard.  We discovered that the discharge of the trash screen to the final tails thickener was partially plugged which caused the tub to fill up and overflow.  We also found that the floor drain in pumphouse #4 was completely covered with trash so no flow was going through there.

Operator was doing a routine round and noticed that the trash screen was overflowing. We (me Cathy Chouinard and Denis Matte) dismantled the ingot from the 4th cast. I pushed after unmolding the 1st brick in the sink and the brick disintegrated following a thermal shock. Beau and Eric were in 5370 pocket pulling Ore and were having trouble with the vibratory feeder tripping out. After investigating they seen that feeder liner has a thin layer of metal coating that has started folding up and stopping the muck from flowing. When it does this it trips the feeder thinking that it is hung up. Until the loose layer is removed we believe there will continue to have vibrator faults.

At around 1:45am there was a power bump that tripped the hoist and the fans. All crews were told to stand down until further notice. The electricians were underground and had to ride 2 shaft to the surface to reset the hoist. MSHA was notified 30 minutes after the hoist went down.

4 Shaft was pulling muck when they had a fault for issues with the brakes. There is muck in the 6580 flasks and muck on the belt. Tomorrow (1-13-21) is weekly shaft inspection so the flasks will need to be emptied when the problem is fixed before people travel below them. Tonight was scheduled for shaft clean down half a shift but was not able to be completed. In total one hour of skipping muck and 4-5 hours of shaft cleaning time were lost.

At approximately 0635 hours an employee contacted security at the COVID-19 screening area advising that his vehicle was not in the employee parking lot.  The employee asked security if there were cameras in the employee parking lot.  Security advised the employee that there were cameras and they would be reviewed once check-ins were completed. At approximately 0730 hours a Sheriff deputy arrived at the mine security office to review camera footage.  The vehicle was recorded on CCTV being taken off the property by an unknown subject.  The vehicle was taken without the employee's knowledge while he was underground in the mine. The footage was shown to the Deputy but unfortunately the subject operating the vehicle cannot be seen clearly through the windshield of the vehicle.

Original diamond drill targets (planned mid-2020) for the upcoming drill station in 655-55 ramp were identified to be within the 50 foot standoff for diamond drill holes from active workings. This was identified during the station planning process. The targets were adjusted to be outside of the 50 feet standard.

While delivering a load of MIBC the delivery pump located on the truck started leaking. The pump was shut down and an estimate of gallons spilled was determined to be less then 5 gallons. Pig pads, booms and "kitty litter" was deployed by LF employees. Distributor was notified and it was determined that the truck should leave the sight to be repaired or off loaded to another truck and will return at a later date.

While performing a sand pour James noticed that his fresh water feed tank was slowly losing level. The system was alarming that the tank was below 4000 gallons.  He inspected the float and verified that flow was going into the tank.  The flow going into the tank was approximately 50 gpm.  The tank continued to slowly drop to near 3000 gallons.  James went back up to the water tank and cycled the float.  The float had gotten stuck partially down so the auto-valve was only adding 50 gpm.  Once he got the float free the fresh water feed to the tank increased to approximately 150 gpm and the tank level began to rise.
3 folding chairs were found leaning against the door of the 120 volt lighting panel.
4 liters of engine oil spilled due to a faulty connection on the Bus.

While touring Denver through Pumphouse 3 I noticed there was grating near the stair walkway that passes over both lines leaving Pumphouse 3.  The grating was bent and once I inspected it more closely I found that it flexed when weight was put on it.
Hydraulic oil spill of 3 liters caused by a faulty connection on the nacelle.
As I landed the split sets on the chisel, I had pain that persisted up to the finger from the right elbow.
After testing the main mine 13.8 breaker trip relay, the relay was being reinstalled into service. Upon powering back up, the unit tripped the main breaker.
Cementation was adding a transformer for the 2 shaft signal power, the 480 volt main was shut off, this action caused the server to go down as they are both hooked together.
A water line in the shaft ruptured causing the muck pulling operation to cease.

A high sump alarm at 003 displayed on the wonderware system at the mill.  I contacted Casey about what was going on because he was at the water plant.  He said that there was water draining thru the spare disc filter to the sump in the disc filter building. Casey shut off the feed to the plant and returned to the mill to pick me up to go back to the plant.  What we determined was that the filter feed had climbed at the disc filter was constantly backwashing.  The level in the disc filter had gotten high enough that it was flowing out the high level discharge pipe.  It looks like the flow thru that pipe was then back draining to the spare filter and draining out the filter drain to the floor and eventually to the sump that alarmed the high level. We decided to slow the flow thru the clarifier after restarting.  Went from 570 gpm to 500 gpm.

*While plugging a hole on the chute from BC9 to standard cone I locked out the Control Power Standard Cone Crusher panel and BC9 at the upper crusher MCC. I placed the bolt through the hole and tightened the nut. *Crusher was down for cleaning and the fine ore bin was full. *I left the area to attend a morning safety meeting without pulling my locks on BC9 and what I believed to be the standard breaker. *While gone operator had finished cleaning and went to fire back up and was able to start the standard cone.

*While preparing to transfer a tote of Z Clear 204 that was being stored on a secondary containment platform into another tote, I noticed the containment was completely full. *This secondary containment gets filled when operators clean the screens for the recycle water on the top floor of the building. The water used while cleaning these screens has historically run down the grating and to the sump. Now we have reagents that need to be stored on the bottom floor of the building and have to be stored on these secondary containments.
Spill of 2 liters of antifreeze caused by a broken hose on the articulated truck 745.
The empty green 2A 134 bus truck made its stop, it left too quickly and the bus from the Casa and we had emergency brakes.

On December 7, I stayed with the grip in the gondola in the air. Mechanical wait 1h. The emergency system was not working. Mechanical repaired, but on the other side. He still remained in the air for 45 minutes.

While adjusting the size of the standard cone crusher, the double jack being used to pound the tightening wedges into place broke at the wooden handle.

While Chris was operating the crushing plant he had the tertiary cone crusher trip out on him.  Chris immediately noticed this and shut down the crushing plant.  He noticed that the dust collector had turned off. He tried many times to reset and restart the dust collector with no luck. He notified his supervisor and the supervisor and other experienced operators went to crushing plant to try to get dust collector started up, all with no success.

Sam was getting a bucket of sand on the right side of the reclaimer building.  He got too close to the reclaimer.  As he was backing out he caught the right side mirror on the reclaimer.  The mirror frame was slightly bent and the mirror itself cracked.

While un-tarping to begin offload procedure at Trail, the driver heard a 'pop' sound. He went to see what it was, and a small fire had started on the truck. The battery had failed next to the hydraulic reservoir and ignited the fluid present in the hoses.

I climbed liner pallets to the sag landing, I put the forks in my pallet and lift a little. Then I got in and wanted to lift my load. The ends of the fork hooked into another pallet and wanting to lower the load to tip.

Around 2:30 AM, I was at garage 810. I was cleaning the transmission filter of the 430 because there was glue on the o-ring and I cut myself with the rim of the filter. I had removed ÇMy gloves so as not to contaminate the new filter.
Two cans of belt dressing were on the ledge with the reclaimer chain, across from the emergency belt discharge chute.  The cans are marked as "Extremely Flammable" and we're not stored properly.

The floor sump in the reagent room mix pit area has the guard removed.  There is ongoing maintenance happening in the area with the pump.  The red danger tape that was marking the area was untied on one side and laying on the ground.
A piece of wood was laying on the floor above the sump grating that had broken off of a pallet.  The board had 6 nails pointing up.
The guard under BC-7 that swings open to clean underneath was missing the bolt that holds it secured in place.  The bolt was laying on the ground near the area.
While Operating the crusher the operator removed a 5" round section of solid metal from the crusher feed belt BC6.

Chris noticed on the camera in the tertiary room that the lighting appeared very dim in there.  When he went to investigate he found that the tripod light on the top floor of the room was off.  He noticed that the power cord was hanging down.  He went to the lower floor to get the plug to plug it back in.  He found that the cord had dropped down and wedged between the tertiary motor and the belt guards.

While doing a routine check on the sand plant circuit and operators I noticed the whip check on the sparger air added to the front of the drum was not correct.  Both ends of the whip check were on the same side of the fitting.

Casey called his supervisor (Chris Stoddard) to report the effluent pH at 002 was a 6.51, just slightly above our permitted low limit.  We turned off P-60 and the filter feed pump so no flow was going through the filters and discharging to the river.  We then put MMF vessel #1 into a backwash.  After the backwash was complete we restarted the plant knowing that the discharge would not be going to the river but to the backwash effluent page.  We checked the pH during this time and got a 6.6 pH.  We decided to add some lime to P-23 to try to slightly increase the pH through the water circuit.  We started lime pump #2 to P-23 at 10 hz.  We carefully monitored the pH on P-60 while this was running.  When the pH in P-60 started to climb we flushed and shut off lime pump #2.  We continued to closely monitor the effluent pH the remainder of the shift.  The pH slowly climbed during the shift.

While sending sand underground the charge hopper sonar stopped reporting the level in the hopper. Also at this time the the float valve for the fresh water mix tank had stuck open and was overflowing the tank. The Stope had not received sand yet we notified them of our issue and started to send water and flush the line.
While pulling waste , the employees noticed a real strong gassy odor coming from the muck.

I felt a pain in the shoulder towards the elbow as I removed the ferrule in the cage. I have finished raising the floor. I told the hoseman that I was going to see the nurse around 4:45 am. I called the nurse and she told me not to strain my arm too much until I went to see her.

On the morning of Tuesday December 8, at approximately 5:30am, a Zanetti's truck and trailer were loaded with Pb con, when leaving the property the driver exited the normal exit entrance and the trailer came unhooked from the truck.  It appeared that the the penal hitch either broke or was not hooked up properly.  The truck and trailer blocked most of the roadway, we were able to re-route traffic until Zanetti's employees were able to clear the roadway, the truck and trailer were taken back to Zanetti's yard.  Less than 5 gallons of hydraulic oiled spilled on the roadway which was properly cleaned up after the scene was safe to do so.  I(Mike Little) called and talked to Roger at Zanetti's, and they found that the penal hitch was locked in the open position, meaning that the driver offloaded his material and the smelter, hooked his trailer back up and drove it all the way to Osburn without the penal hitch hooked up.
On 12-8-2020 we had a truck incident that spilled approximately 5 gallons or less of hydraulic fluid spilled onto the roadway.  After the scene was safe and secure we cleaned it up

Reese was running the rock breaker to clean the 6500 waste grizzly. It appears the bolts on the breaker head had loosened up and sheared off while racking the muck pile. The hamer fell on to the grizzly. Josh Thomas was able to get a chain on it and lift it out of the pocket. Looks like the mounting plate is bent. The rock breaker was run by R Baldwin, J Thomas, B Rasmussen, and R Doney thru out the night and none of us realized the head was loosening up. This seems to be a weak area with this style of hammer. The ore pocket is down the same way now, and it happened on the ore breaker before.

On 11/14/20 at around 10:15 Pm i was headed to the station for the fire drill, i got to 52 ramp started up 52 ramp, i heard some grinding  let off and then pushed back down on the pedal. i was just above the sub station, and it was like the grader went in to neutral and started backwards down the ramp. i tried to put the blade down to slow it down, running it along the rib to slow the grader down. before i knew it i was at the connection and i hit the rib just off the old slot. Tasha and David were double stacking lime bags in loadout.  Tasha went to place a bag on lime on top of another bag.  After she had placed it down the lime in the bottom bag shifted causing the top bag to shift and lean to the left.  It was tilted enough that she was unable to get both forks into the pallet to correct it.  At that time, Casey Nelson came through the area.  Casey went and checked out the Komatsu forklift so he could assist.  Casey was able to hook the handle of the lime bag and lift it up to provide support so bag would not tip.  Tasha then was able to use the right fork of her forklift to go inside the left side of the pallet.  She lifted the pallet up slightly and Casey was able to pull his fork out of the handle of the lime bag.  Casey then used left fork in the right side of the pallet.  They were able to lift the pallet evenly and back up until they were clear of the bottom lime bag and then lowered the bag back down to the ground.

An employee was running the 6500 Ore rock breaker and had some bolts break that held the bull prick head on. Crushing employee found some explosives on the BC-6 feed belt.  He removed the explosives and secured them in the explosives lock box in the crushing plant.  He notified his supervisor. On his first round at 003 a mill ops employee noticed that the seeps flow was reading 0 gpm.  He notified his supervisor and went to the seeps pump to investigate.  He first verified that the level in the pumpbox was still down but saw that there was no discharge to the 003 surge tank.  He then went to check the valves on the side of the pond to see if flow had been swapped to Pond 3 but it was still valved to the surge tank. At that point the Supervisor and another employee headed out to help investigate. They attempted to rack out both the primary and secondary pumps and reset them.  When they racked out the secondary he discovered that the breaker handle was broken and not able to rack back in.  We were able to get the primary pump running again and were showing flow to the 003 surge.  Once they got that running, they proceeded back to the electrical shop to get an electrician to rack the secondary pump back in.  He was able to locate an electrician and he immediately came out to get the pump running.  The electrician and mill employee verified that the secondary pump was running before leaving the area.

Lost Power to the Island at 1:24 am, Brad Shulze was dispatched to power house to start generation.  Hawk Inlet generation switched on auto with no issues.  Rick Freed was at the 920 and brought the lights back on, All power was restored at the 920 and stable around 3:00 am.  The only issue was the sag motor had a fault with the RTD electricians worked with the electricians on channel 1 to resolve the fault.  Jeff Swanson, Chet Creamer and Jody Squires went up to check the road at 4:00 am and pulled into  4.7 to talk to Mike Stocks and Jesse Boudreau.  After talking to Mike Stocks we sat at 4.7 to observe the trees crashing and talking.  The decision was made to leave 4.7 and go back to camp to inform the Green Creek team the road was closed until daylight so we could access the damage.  At this point we informed the electricians there may be power lines down and would need their help.  Went back up to 4.7 with the three electricians and pulled off.  We had Brian Tatlow and Mike Flansas head down the hill at 8:00 am so we could have the daylight to access the road.  The road was cleared to 4.7 around 8:10.  Everyone was told to re-group at 4.7 to discuss the road conditions with Brian Tatlow who had just cleared the road.  The report was the road was accessible to go to go to the 920 to get the high voltage gear to deal with any highline issues.  The loader and three pickups proceeded up to the 920, right at 4.8 there was a micro burst and we tried to go back to the 4.7, the trees blew down on the trucks, powerline and road.  This snapped power poles and powerlines for at least or close to a mile.  The rear pickup was able to clear themselves after a tree had damaged the bed.  The loader and the two trucks were able to work there way to the 4.9 turn out.  The situation was re-assessed, everyone was safe and okay.  It was then re-assessed that we had to cut our way back out to the 4.7.   Cut the trees out of the road and went back to camp make a new plan and arrange helicopters for a crew change.

All information in this description is from interview with Darren Hei. Francis and Darren were hanging 4/0 15KV Cable onto messenger cable.  They both worked for just under an hour before taking their first break.  During their break they both rested and re-hydrated.  They then had to get a tele-handler to work out of due to the higher back.  This event extended their resting time.  After continuing to work for a while later, Francis stated that he wasn't feeling good and needed to take a break which he did.  Darren continued working until he came to an area where he needed help.  Francis helped him finish and then both returned to the surface.  Francis then told Darren that he wasn't feeling well and went home early.  According to Darren, who is an experienced underground worker, it was not overly hot in the ramp and there were no other equipment working in the area.  Darren stated there were some contributing factors to this incident.  Francis was off for a week, worked one day dayshift and then switched to nightshift the next day.  He was unable to get to sleep the day before and told Darren he had worked on his new house during the day.  Francis also told Darren before they started to work that he didn't feel real good and had a headache but was well enough to work.

Day shift could not get the rounds to blast using the new Ikon system. It would read too much voltage loss. They went to the headings and tried everything that they could think of to fix it but had no luck and decided to hoist to the surface.  I called Byron at home and we talked about somethings that might work. I took Danny Smith underground with me. We tried everything that Byron and I had talked about to shoot the rounds. I made a decision to shoot the rounds with fuse primers so we could get the crew to work. Danny and I preceded to 16 stope and tied on fuses and lite them and reset the fan. We than went to 56 vent drift and tied a fuse on, lite it and reset the fan. Finally we went to 19 stope and tied and lite a fuse in 110W, reset fan and preceded to the shifters office.After all the rounds had gone, I called Josh Thomas and told him at 8:00pm to start brining the crew down. I feel this was enough delay that some rounds we missed on night shift

I came up to the airdoor at 4900 station from the back side and someone had left the station side airdoor open. I bled off the valves in their 1,2,3 order but the pressure on the door was far to much for me to push it open. Underground called the paste plant and said they were ready to flush the pour. I notified the loader operator to quit filling the hopper.  I let the hopper empty out.  When the hopper got close to empty I set the cement to 0 lbs.  When the last of the sand dumped into the mixer there was 96 lbs in the hopper.  I set the batch amount to 80 lbs and hit CF auto start for the program.  When it was time for the sand to drop for the final batch it wouldn't drop.  The system wouldn't go into auto shut down because the sand was just sitting in the hopper.  We put the system in manual and got water flushing the line so nothing would plug up.  We manually got the mixers going and dumped the last of the sand into the mixer and then dumped it down so the pump could get rid of the last of it.  We finished the flush with the system in manual and shut it down.

On the morning of September 21st we began receiving shotcrete through the ore feed.  This in turn corrupted our flotation by greatly altering the pH. This pH swing was made its way through flotation and eventually through to the water treatment plants.  As the pH at WTP-002 increased into 9.0 range we decided to stop discharging our effluent and instead would recycle to ensure we did not exceed the daily maximum pH range.  As this was going on more slurry was accumulating in the flotation basement which would eventually make it's way to tails and ultimately through water.  We attempted to send most of this material through the Geho lines to Pond 4 but some would ultimately overflow the thickener and head towards treatment.  By the time we were able to startup WTP-002, which was about 36 hours later, we knew we would have more solids so we increased PTB-50, the flocculant and the coagulant in the system.  We took our compliance sample on Thursday and ultimately failed compliance due to having both high dissolved lead and high particulate lead in our sample.  This continued to be a problem through the weekend even with water balance changes that were made and ultimately the plant was shut down until we can assure we are treating the water appropriately.  This resulted in a maximum daily limit exceedance for Outfall 002 on the 9/25/2020 compliance sample.  The investigation is ongoing.

Approximately 7am a contractor and maintenance employee were inspecting the Ball Mill Auto Lube filters.  The Contractor was removing the cover lid on the one filter in bypass.  The filters are located on the west, back side of the Lube Control Panel.  The maintenance contractor was wearing a tape measure on his hip, when it came in contact with the "stop" button on the panel.  The Ball Mill lubrication fail safe was triggered as flow to the bearings was stopped.  The Ball Mill immediately turned off as did the feed conveyors.  The Auto Lube System must never be shut down before the Ball Mill has completely ceased rotating.

A trunnion housing inspection plate was reported as leaking lubrication oil.  Trunnion bearing housings are located at each end of the Ball Mill.  Each housing has 2 inspection plates.  NDT by Ultron was completed on 9/2 and did require the removal of all bearing inspection plates.  The plates were reattached, but not by Hecla Millwrights.  The plates were not inspected for bolt torque or tightening before the Ball Mill was started.  Upon inspection, it was evident that some bolts were loose on two plates.  The plates are not accessible while the Ball Mill is operating.  Due to safety, Maintenance made a request to Operations to grind out the Ball Mill, then stop it to tighten and check all four plates.  The Ball Mill was ground out for 25 minutes, then stopped for 10 minutes.  All plates were inspected and bolts were hand torqued.

At shift change the operator noticed something different with the lead flash cell.  We noticed the ore turning a light gray.  Everything was really frothy and our pumps couldn't pump it even with water pushing it.  The lead flash cell was turned down so much on air and level it was still coming over the top.  We couldn't control anything at all, a lot of pumps boiled over constantly.  At first we didn't know what was causing these problems and we tried to remedy by adjusting reagents.  Later in the shift our crusher operator began finding chunks of shotcrete on the feed belt.  Once he let us know what he was seeing we had him begin collecting all the shotcrete off the belt and saving it for inspection.  Once we determined there was a significant amount of shotcrete in the feed we were determined that this was the root cause of our problems with pH in the flotation circuit and water.  We had to shut down WTP 002  due to the high pH coming through so that we didn't violate our permit. The mill was shutdown shortly after because we were unable to control the circuit.

Alaska Stormwater Maintenance (ASM) was on-site to perform a CCTV inspection of the primary pipe that drains Pond 9 and discharges to the West Buttress Ditch on the back side of tails. The purpose of the inspection was to determine if there was any sediment buildup and assess the integrity of the pipe to determine if additional load (i.e. increase the height of the tailings stack) could be applied as part of the North Extension project. 
The pipe is ~18" ID HDPE (~23.5", DR9) with butt-fusion welds every ~40 feet and is approximately 800 feet long. The fusion beads are approximately 1" thick. 
ASM begin their inspection at the upstream end of the pipe in the Pond 9 caisson. Proper confined space entry procedures were followed. The camera was set in the pipe and began tramming down the pipe. ASM was able to successfully get the camera approximately 600 feet down the pipe before they were unable to cross a fusion bead. In efforts to cross the bead ASM indicates the data cable may have gotten looped around one of the wheels on the camera carrier, but this is not certain. After failing to cross the bead ASM began to retrieve the camera. 
The video footage shows that as the camera was pulled back out of the pipe the camera would occasional ride up on the side of the pipe and partially tip over, but then right itself as it was pulled out. This progressed until the camera was approximately 320 feet from the pipe inlet at which time the camera flipped on its side and became stuck against a fusion bead.
The contractor attempted to flush the camera downgradient by placing a piece of pipe over the caisson inlet and allowing water to build up in the caisson and then removing the plywood using a line attached to the plywood. However, with approximately 300 feet of cable attached to the camera flushing did not work. 
When flushing didn't work ASM made the decision to attempt to pull the camera out so they attached a come-along to the cable, a large shackle to the 16" pipe on the opposite side of the caisson and pulled until the cable parted off. Almost all of the cable was retrieved, but the camera is still stuck in the pipe. 
ASM subsequently packaged up the rest of their gear and left site.

The seismic system quit functioning on dayshift August 5, 2020 and was not functioning until August 7, 2020 day shift.  During the outage, the 30 vein stopes (32 slot, 15 stope, 16 stope) that are seismically active were not worked.  Other headings not considered seismically active were mined - 19 stope, 50 ramp, 56 ramp.  There were three lost shifts of production from the 30 vein stopes - 8/5 nights and 8/6 days and nights.  
The fiber in 54 ramp was found broken.

At approximately 3:40PM on Sept 10, 2020, a miner contacted the hoist operator and stated that they need to clean under the vibratory feeder and required shutting down the flask feed belt.  After deactivation of said belt, the cager put the belt in "local" mode to run the belt.  Moments later, he then activated the vibratory feeder in "local" mode.  A mechanic tried to stop the employee from doing this however it was too late.  The result was an overload of the feed belt.  The incident resulted in no personal injury, no equipment damage, or property damage.

Early in the shift we started getting higher winds causing us to loose communication to WTP 003, suspecting power or communication loss Rocky and I were able to catch the plant shut down immediately and had it back online in a matter of minutes after verifying that the Secondary seeps pump was working. After getting WTP 003 running I went and reset the VFD for the Primary pump. Later in the shift we experienced another communication loss to WTP 003 due to weather,after the second time communication was lost to WTP 003 we had the plant back online immediately after verifying that the Secondary pump in the seeps was running. I reset the VFD for the Primary seeps pump once again and waited for it to start pumping, it can take a few hours before the Primary pump will run properly off the level of the seeps. After a few times of the Secondary pump having to kick on I had electricians trouble shoot why the Primary pump was not running. Shortly after arriving the electricians determined the pump itself was B/O, I called maintenance out and we switched the bad pump out. I verified that the primary pump was working and not relying on the Secondary pump to keep the level down before maintenance and electricians left.

We discovered that it tipped forward because too much heavy materials had been stored in the top drawer and it pulled it over when drawer was open all the way.

A member of the public called to report that the rail road grade is dusting badly. There was an elevated lead result at Outfall 002 from the weekly compliance sample collected at Outfall 002. This lead result, at 30.7 Êg/L, is below the maximum daily limit for Outfall 002. But is within 80% of the limit and is therefore a near miss.

Average monthly effluent limitation exceedance for lead at 002 in July 2020. All four weekly samples collected in July were below the permitted daily max limits. The monthly exceedance was due to a single elevated lead result collected on July 21st. The elevated lead was the consequence of a pH imbalance in Water Treatment Plant 2?s Multi Media Filtration Vessels due to biological fouling.

An employee was operating the Cat 950 Loader during a sand pour when he inadvertently loaded a yellow equipment wheel chock into the Emergency Belt feeder. The wheel chock plugged the hopper discharge belt, causing the sand pour to be shut down. The 19 stope crew was contacted and told that a flush was being sent. Later, the e-belt was LOTO and employees dug out the wheel chock. The entry way into the sand storage building is a transition from bright outside daylight to a dark storage bunker. The employee was partially impaired from this and loaded up a chock that had previously dislodged from it's hanger located on the rear of the equipment. There is a WO turned in for better hanger/baskets to secure wheel chocks to the loader.

During delivery of shotcrete via the slick line, load number four (of four) plugged the bottom of the slick line. The crew receiving the shotcrete followed procedure to unplug the line.  When the line broke free, a Victaulic fitting failed.  The trunk line for filling trucks whipped around and damaged lighting.  The crew flushed the line to ensure it was clear and made repairs.

While off loading super sacks of hydrated lime for the mill, the operator was stacking one bag on top of another in the reagent building. This has become a common practice while loadout has been full of concentrate. The back door of the reagent building was open, which is normally closed during regular operations. This particular area that we were utilizing for storage is located next to our Zinc Sulfate solution storage tank and the bottom drain could've easily been damaged when the super sack rolled off the top pallet and onto the floor. If the drain had been damaged we would have not been able to stop the flow of Zn sulfate and the entirety of the tank would have ended up in our emergency sump area, creating additional hazards. In total approximately 25 gallons came out of the toppled super sack and 5-10 gallons came out of the bag that was next to the bag which toppled. All spilled material ended up on the outside of the building.

After filling the fine ore bin, the crushing plant operator shut down the crushing plant.  Another employee was helping him clean up and went to clean the magnet.  The employee noticed that there was no metal that dropped from the magnet.  Another employee was called for help and when they got up there, they cycled the power on and off to the magnet and it still was not working.  The electricians were called but they were underground.  They said that they would get to it as soon as they could.

EE went to fire up the crushing plant after his lunch break.  When he went to start up the standard cone it seized up.  Jordan immediately shut the cone crusher down.  The employee got help and they were able to back the standard cone off 2 holes and tried to fire it up again with no luck. Upon further inspection a drill bit was found wedged in the cone.  Additional help was called 4 employees were able to back the cone off further and pry the drill bit out.  Once the bit was out the cone was tightened back up and sized to the correct size before restarting the crushing plant.

EE was crushing when he heard something non-rock go through the standard cone crusher.  He investigated and found a drill bit on the belt.  He then checked the magnet and noticed there was no metal stuck to it.  He tested the magnet and it wasn't picking up metal.  He reset the magnet multiple times and it still would not pick anything up.  Once resetting the magnet didn't work, the supervisor called an electrician on the pager phone.  The electrician said that they were all underground but were about to head to the surface.  They would go to the crushing plant once they were on the surface.

The seismic system quit functioning on dayshift August 5, 2020 and was not functioning until August 7, 2020 day shift.  During the outage, the 30 vein stopes (32 slot, 15 stope, 16 stope) that are seismically active were not worked.  Other headings not considered seismically active were mined - 19 stope, 50 ramp, 56 ramp.  There were three lost shifts of production from the 30 vein stopes - 8/5 nights and 8/6 days and nights.

The crushing plant was down for approx 2 hours.

While making adjustments on the ZN flash cell an employee noticed that the float ball level indicator and the housing that holds it in place had busted off and was floating around in the Zn flash cell. The only thing keeping it from sinking and potentially causing harm to agitator or the possibly the pump was a half inch water hose that is hooked to the housing to rinse the device.

Lost air to the PB and Zn flash cells and scavengers on both sides as well. Swapped blowers from the 60hp to the 40hp and this did nothing to help our situation. Fought this for aprx 10 min before killing feed and starting a grind out while we further investigated what the issue was. Traced lines to every destination from the main line and started isolating them where we could to see where the loss of air was coming from. After 40 min we had figured out that when we isolated the air line that feeds the Zn flash cell we would get air everywhere else. Feed was off for right at 45min before we found and isolated our problem line and then restarted feed and left the air off to the flash. Made the decision to stay running without the Zn flash and pulled every other section of the Zn circuit as hard as we could.

When attempting to calibrate the Thermo Scientific Orion Star A121 hand-held pH probe, this morning prior to sampling, the "Buff" error kept flashing. We replaced the buffer sollutions and cleaned the probe using a mild cleaning acid, however the error kept appearing. 
I troubleshot the probe and realized that the probe readings were significantly off. We had a spare pH probe, so I attached that to the hand-held device and was able to successfully calibrate. We used the spare probe to sample today.
I plan on contacting Thermo Scientific to troubleshoot further. This probe is new, we received it on 6/15/20 and immediately put it into use as our compliance pH probe. I used the probe yesterday and it had calibrated normally and was reading correctly while I was sampling.

Every Monday, we download data, calibrate, and field check the in-stream pH/temperature devices (sondes) that are above stream and below stream each outfall. On the 13th, I checked the sonde at BL#3 and found that the device's pH was reading lower then the grab sample I had just done with the hand-held pH meter. Looking at the data, it looked like the pH had been lower then normal since the last calibration on the 7th. 
I calibrated the sonde and was still getting a lower value then the hand-held. So I pulled the device out of the river and replaced it with the sonde from AB#1. I'm currently sending the initial sonde to the manufacturer for repair. 
In order to prevent this issue from occurring in the future, or at the very least reducing the chance that we didn't catch it in time, we are going to check the hand-held pH meter against the sondes every business day and recalibrate when needed. We have ordered a device from In-situ that will allow us to see the data from the sondes in real time at our computers, however we are still waiting for this to be shipped.

The in-stream pH/temperature device (sonde) at BL#2 did not take a reading between 7/7/2020 and 7/13/2020. The log on the device had been paused on the 7th to calibrate and was never resumed once calibration ended. 
This is considered an environmental noncompliance and will be reported to the regulators on the July discharge monitoring report (DMR).In order to prevent this issue from occurring in the future, we are going to check the sondes every business day to make sure the log is running. We have ordered a device from In-situ that will allow us to see the data from the sondes in real time at our computers, however we are still waiting for this to be shipped.

After inspecting P-3B, an attempt to place the pump back on line failed due to sand buildup at the intake and discharge air actuated knife gates.  The spair P-3A pump was running but needed to be placed off line for repairs.  In an attempt to keep the Ball Mill running, a millwright crawled under the guard and used a pry bar to lift the knife gate manually, allowing the pump to be successfully placed on line.

Maintenance received a call that truck 4203 was at the top of  the ramp by the air doors on the lateral and had a check engine light on. A mechanic went to check it out. He looked the machine over and shut it all down by the master switch.  He then powered it all back up and the engine light went away. They turned it loose. A little while later maintenance received another call that the engine light was on and this time the Red stop engine light was on too. When we checked on it the engine was making funny noises and showing a engine code "NO OIL pressure". The next shift mechanic crew, someone went down and plugged the computer in to check codes, that is when they discovered the no oil pressure, and a record of over REVVED condition. The data log shows that the engine had been over revved a couple of times approximately 300 engine hrs before engine failure. This over revved condition may have not caused the immediate engine failure but surely contributed to its decline.

When sampling the effluent at 002, the new hand held Thermo-scientific pH probe read 6.5. However, the Mill's hand held pH probe showed 7.5 on the same sample. The Mill data showed pH of mid 7 for the past 24hours leading up to this point.
I immediately re-calibrated the pH probe. When this didn't solve the issue, I used the mill pH data in the sample log book as per our QAP.  
I brought the probe back to the office and ran a series of tests on it, comparing its readings to the YSI pH probe as well as the Hach probes at the mill.

15 stope had called for water and got a good full head of water at the stope and then called for sand they had just started to get sand when they lost everything coming out of the end of the pipe. Upon investigation they realized that the sand line had blown apart at the old 6400 slot. They called for water once the line was flushed, they then hooked up a header to the pipe going to the stope to flush from there down. Once the 40' section of pipe was changed out and hooked back up they called for water. they were getting water to the stope but not a good full head the sandplant advised the crew that the pressures were building much higher than normal with water. They shut down and broke the line again at the old slot and it was determined that there was a partial blockage between there and the stope. They started hooking up headers and blowing lines back from the stope, nightshift took over where they left off and were able to get the line cleaned out and start pouring again today.

When I, Mike Little arrived for my shift, the crew that was on was having some issues with the zinc ods pump plugging off.  We got some flow going and filter back on-line and things were ok for shift change.  Oncoming crew member Rocky Kimmel went to check filter room and noticed the flow to the zinc vat had changed, Cord and I went back to help investigate, we did a series of quick test and determined that the ods was plugged.  The Zinc circuit was very loaded up so with the circumstances going on we reduced TPH to 38 from 45-46 at 6:30pm.  We did a fairly common practice to get ods unplugged, the line was clear to the vat, diaphragm section was flushed and cleared. and then we noticed what is referred to as the cone, very bottom section of the thickener was cleared.  With all the drains open we could see clumps of zinc fall in the cone from the thickener be, we tried air lance up into the bed, put the hotsy line up in the bed of the thickener and didn't have any success unblocking the plug.  A call was made to the foreman and we discussed shutting down the mill, until we could fix the problem, starting shutting down at 9:30pm.  As we shut down and reduced flow to the Thickener, I stuck a 20' pvc pipe into the top of the thickener and hit solids about a 2 feet in.  We estimated that it was appx. 80% full of packed in ZN con.  Also we noticed that there was 104 on the pressure gauge and 2 on the rake torque.  We had an idea that the rakes were broke, but the shaft was still spinning.  We spent the majority of 3 shifts emptying out the thickener, day shift was to make quite a bit of shippable cons, until density became and issue.  We spent last night cleaning the rest of the material out so maintenance can develop a plan to fix the rakes, which the drive shaft twisted and broke from the rakes.

While loading out trucks for concentrate shipping, the toolbox hinge on the 928G loader failed. By the time the contracted operator realized what had happened, the lid to the toolbox had already become bent. He secured it closed with a bungy cord and finished loading trucks.

I was adjusting the relief valve on the inching drive and unscrewing oil gushed out of the hose. I had it on my clothes and other workers present as well. Some of them had a few drops on their faces, I asked if everyone was correct, I was told yes.

Michelle Horning was exiting her vehicle on the mine dump and noticed an assault rifle in the back seat of the vehicle parked next to her. She immediately make contact with Chris Neville, who in turn contacted myself to go check out the vehicle. I figured it belonged to one of the new security guards taking their 40 hour training in the training room.  I went to the room and asked the two new guards whose car it was. I then asked the guard to come with me.

Turned on new water supply pump at 2800 silver shaft station. The pump is to supply water to 2800/2600 2 Shaft repair. Approximately 500' of the water supply lines was old pipe with the rest of the pipe having been replaced. When the pump was started, a hole blew out in the old pipe.

Aaron Mitchell called me at 2:30am and told me that his clarifier underflow to the floor sump dump valve had stuck open.  I Mike Little,  rushed out to the plant and tried to figure out what was going on.  Cord Jensen gave us an idea of a process to use to get valve unstuck and it did not work.  Cord came in and switched some air line back and forth and finally the valve closed.  This underflow valve dumps a 6" line to the floor sump and has a timer button.  The air to the timer button has been locked out for over the two years I have been back and has not been a common practice to use for years because the valve had stuck on prior operators and flooded out the building.  We have an alternate way of dumping the clarifier that does not put it to the floor, rather to P-52 which reports to the Final tails thickener.  I asked Aaron why he decided to use this process, and he was told that another crew said they used it and the timer valved worked.  There was no ops lock or anything blocking this method that has been locked for several years.  So in conclusion, someone decided to remove the ops lock and start using this process that has failed in the past.  Booms were in place at the roll up door and all the solids from clarifier settled in the sump and in the building, appx 75-100 gallons of clean water made its way out the door, running directly into the event pond
Unauthorized, terminated employee had access to the mine property

I have the impression that I got stuck in my legs. I fell to the ground, I went to see my colleague and we decided to take a break. When we got outside they came to see us because he thought we were out because of the evacuation.

20' pipe in a dust pan was being unloaded off of the cage at the 5900 station.  The cage was stopped around the top deck and the cager used the forklift to pushed the dustpan off the top Johnson bar to remove it from the cage.  After the bar was removed the cage was belled up so that the lower Johnson bar could be removed.  The hoistman began to move the hoist up and his finger must not of been all the way on the stick button which caused the cage to move up at a high rate of speed and causing the lower Johnson bar and lower deck to collide with the forks on the forklift lifting it up off the ground before the cage came to a stop.

Western States mechanic was working on the 236B CAT skidsteer.  He called me at 950am to inform me that he needs to order parts.  He would be underground the next two days, parts will arrive during this time, in which he could install them when he got back to surface.  He asked me if he needed to put the machine back together for 2 days of operation.  I told him no, will leave tagged out.  Around noon, I was walking to PH4 and noticed the skidsteer bucket arms elevated to maximum height, with no one around.  The locking arm support was in place. Jordan was doing samples in WTP 002 when he noticed that the bleach was empty and he was not getting flow. He batched bleach and continued through the circuit grabbing samples in pump house 4. While coming back through 002 he noticed that both the PTB-50 and the bleach had tripped out and were off. He reset the outlet for both masterflex pumps, but they again tripped out instantly. He called me out and we began to stretch out extension cords from other power sources so we could re-establish the PTB-50 flow ASAP. After trying the new power source to both pumps we found that the issue was in the bleach pump.

Two employees were coming up 56 ramp in a kubota while Shaun was coming down in a haul truck. At 190 2705 124-16, May 19, 2020, Wanting to put a trellis at the back (with the screwdriver), the trellis went backwards. I tried to hold it back to put it back on, then I felt a pain or rather a point on the left side but not in the back. I stopped immediately.

During a fire drill the driller & drill helper did not report in to the hoistmen or the shifter. They did not leave their station and had to be retrieved. On Wednesday (the day before the drill), the driller reported smelling stench in the drill station twice. Each time he called in, he was informed it was only a drill. During the day of the fire drill, the driller was unaware he had a sinus infection that significantly restricted his sense of smell. When he asked his helper if he smelled stench, the helper said yes, but that it wasn't very strong. When the driller and helper went to the radio to report in, they saw trucks operating and heard traffic on the radio that the sandplant was still operating. Assuming it was just continued maintenance on the stench system, they returned to work without reporting in.
