While taking samples and checking levels and numbers in WTP002 Sid entered PH4 and noticed that he had lost PSI on the P52 pump gland water. He traced the line and quickly found another water supply system to feed the gland water on pump and called his supervisor. P52 when it lost its gland water was over pressured by the slurry going through the pump itself and charged the glands freshwater feed line with slurry which immediately filled both floc tanks in the building when they went to batch. The dirty sand water that went into the tanks damaged the 558 floc pumps mechanical seal. (The pump that feeds the sand plant)

AT 8:00 PM I RECEIVED A CALL FROM SCOTT CAMPBELL IN 15 STOPE W THAT HIS ROUND DID NOT GO OFF WITH THE DAYSHIFT BLAST ROUNDS, THEN HE ASKED ME TO COME DOWN AND SHOW ME WHAT HE HAD FOUND. SO ANTON MAREK AND MYSELF WENT DOWN THERE TO SEE WHAT HAD HAPPENED. WHAT WE FOUND IS THAT THE ONE LEAD WIRE COMING FROM THE ELECTRIC PRIMER WAS NOT CONNECTED TO THE LEAD WIRE COMING FROM THE BLASTING LINE IN THE STOPE, WE ALSO FOUND THAT THE ELECTRIC PRIMER WAS NOT PROPERLY CONNECTED TO THE DET CORD.

The mechanic's just finished their daily checks on the hoist when the hoist tripped out. The hoistman tried to reset the hoist with no success.  The hoistman then tried to restart the hoist with the same result.  At 7:48am the Silver Shaft Hoistman and underground shifter were notified at which time all employees underground were put on a stand down .  At 7:55 am the electricians came to the hoist room and at 8:00am the mechanics showed up to diagnose the problem.  At 8:15 am a call to MSHA's immediately reportable line was made to inform them that the hoist was down and at that time we began evacuating the underground.

Chubba went to blast rounds at the end of nightshift and the 16 stopes rounds did not go off. He then ran down to 16 stope and 36 slot and 56 down ramp because they are all on the same line to check things out. He did not find anything that appeared to be wrong and everything check out with the Galvanometer. He  then went back to the service shop and tried to blast the rounds again and they still did not go. At that point he left it and come up from underground and informed dayshift coming on that the rounds did not go in these areas.

An Employee was operating the crushing plant when the ore recirculating back to his standard cone became to large and steady for the cone to handle. The ore stopped the standard cone and the employee quickly stopped all belts feeding it and everything else in the plant and called me immediately.

EE shut down the crusher while the fine ore bin was high and did cleanup in the plant. I noticed that he was down and attempted to reach him on the radio. After a few minutes of trying to reach him I went up to the crusher to investigate what was going on. He was just getting ready to fire the plant back up so I decided to stay and watch him bring it on-line. While going through the process of following the numbered #s 1-14 to bring the whole plant up he got to #10 and then hit #14 next which starts the feed to all belts while both BC11 and BC12 were not yet running.

An employee was moving and stacking all reagents in the load-out bay when his forks made contact with a sodium bisulfide bag in the row he was stacking in. There was a total of about two gallons of powder that hit the ground that we had to shovel up and put back.

While moving the 10 ton bridge crane 1 of the pulleys that hold the power wire to the messenger cable wore through and hung up on the cable. Which pulled the power cable out of bridge crane     power J box. The strain relief cable failed to hold the power cable from slipping through its anchor.
There was no indication or pre warning that this was about to happen. The plastic pulley sheeve that runs on the messenger cable had worn down in the center of the groove until it broke in half which made it bind up on the messenger cable. The lead pulley shows the most wear, due to its location to the bridge and slightly changing angles, when the bridge changes travel directions.

Saturday Morning 4/4/20 I over heard some of the crew talking about the CAT grader EQ114282 while riding the skip UG. They were discussing the size of it, the use of it, and what not. I did not pay much attention until it was brought up that we (maintenance) just preformed a 100 hr. service on it, and Dominic Mitchell (I think that is his name) asked why we moved back to its parking spot when there is still unfinished work to do to it?  Like it needs the cutting edge replaced the fuel cap won't close like it had been bent or something.  That made me curious and I decided to go take a look at it, I first checked out the grader blade, then climbed up looking over the operator compartment where I found the seat belt not functioning like was mentioned. I then look down the hood toward the fuel fill cap and saw that everything on top of the hood had damage. The coolant over flow bottle yellow cover was no where to be found (it had been completely ripped off the hood) and the coolant bottle top was almost torn clear off the bottle, and had a rag wrapped around the neck. The exhaust was damaged(bent) and the exhaust wrap was peeled of the tail pipe to about half way back. The air bonnet had scratches on it. The fuel cap would not fit because the filler neck which is part of the fuel tank assy. is bent preventing the cap from fitting.
Zinc Sulfate Spill in Reagent Room

There was a leaking fitting on the gear tac lube system found while doing a walk-through. I called for assistance from the on shift maintenance guy to come and inspect. Upon arrival the mechanic thought he would be able to pull the loose fitting and tape it up and re-install and stop the leak. Mechanic completed what he thought would help and then let me know what he had done. After watching the pump kick on several more times the leak was continuously getting worse and I called the mechanic back to the location and asked if had what he needed to swap out the fitting that was leaking with a new one in hopes this would stop our steady leaking gear tac issue. Mechanic came up with parts that he believed would get us through the night and into day shift when there would be more personnel and experience in dealing with this system.  Mechanic took apart the fitting and started to replace the leaking setup with what he had built, but by the time he had it put back together an audible alarm had went off for the lube system. We were able to silence the alarm and the mechanic was able to quickly finish his job and we could see locally that the pump was indeed starting and cycling in a normal like fashion, however the alarm continued to sound off every 3-5 minutes and needed reset. I let it go off 3 times in hopes that it may just need to reestablish flow and pressure. Once it went off a 4th time I called the maintenance general foreman for help and to answer some questions. He was able to get a hold of one of his experienced hands to come on site and assist with further tests and troubleshooting. After about an hour we had come to fact that we would need to grind out and prep the mills for shutdown so maintenance could further test and diagnose the issue. Maintenance replace the spray nozzle on the gear lube line thinking it may be plugged. This did not work and they ended up replacing the solenoid box that actuates and lets lube spray as needed before we were able to fire back up.

While touring underground on Monday, we stopped at the 5900 Shifter Shack to get a workplace inspection card.  When we came back out to get our Kubota a haul truck was going by and we noticed the operator was not wearing ear muffs.  The operator was stopped and asked where their ear muffs were.  The operator responded that they were not aware that they were required to wear them on a haul truck.  The operator was really surprised when he was told about the requirement which indicates that we have a gap in our training program.

The mine superintendent entered the shop and notified the two supervisors that there was a truck tire staged on the station behind the rock breaker that was blocking access to the electrical panel. Kellogg Police Department received a report of shots fired near the Smelterville core shed. 4 officers entered the core shed forcefully with guns drawn, suspecting it might contain the suspected shooter. We were doing a pour and we had good communication at the start with a hand-held leaky feeder radio because the base station was not working, no comms.  U/G staff gave us an update that they were close to 8'.  I directed to slow the loader operator down to limit the product so we could achieve an efficient flush out when directed by U/G staff.  Approximately 30 minutes elapsed and he got a really poor transmission on the radio, we thought we could make out that they were saying send flush, we transmitted back and nobody could here us, we tried several times to no avail.  I got on the pager phone and the hoist operator was able to contact somebody associated with the flush and the operator told us to send water, we could not hear any of their conversation on any radio.  We sent water for approximately 40-45 minutes, rough 5500 gallons of water as a flush and no communication that they received clear water was made.  I then got on the pager phone and the hoist operator was able to contact them and they confirmed the flush was complete and we could stop sending water.

At approx. 3pm the Environmental Technician called the relief Supervisor and told him that we need to shutdown water filtration plant 002 because she visually observed anthracite around the discharge pipe in the river.  The relief Supervisor and crew members shut down the plant in a controlled but swift manner.  After some inspection it was found that a significant amount of anthracite was in the clean water backwash tank, after a backwash is complete in a vessel the water in the C.W.B.T must be refilled as it uses 30% of the tank in the backwash process, so all the outfall water reports to it and then reports to the river.  The C.W.B.T. caught the majority of the anthracite and then a minimal amount was discharged to the river.  We did some further testing through the plant and measured each vessel and determined that the #1 MMF vessel was the problem.  We Performed a LOTO on the #1 vessel and removed the lid so further investigation can be done  determine what the actual failure was.  This Vessel was recently re-built in December.

It was brought to my attention that something was wrong at our Water Filtration 003 plant according to our trends.  I quickly notified operator and it was discovered that electricians repaired the agitator in the aging tank.  After getting it repaired they must have turned it on.  The other agitator had been turned up to help agitation while the inoperable was down.  There was also and air lance inserted in the tank to help agitation.  When they turned on the inoperable one they turned it on and up to match the speed of the working one, with both of them working, turned up, and the air lance still on and in the tank, it caused a disruption to the filtration process, stirring up a bunch of material and overloading the clarifier, blinding off the Disc filter and sending it into continuous backwashing cycles.  This also causes our Effluent numbers to rise.  This was caught quick and we were able to remedy the situation before any detrimental environmental release took place.  We also got lucky that the air lance and air hose was not tangled up in the agitator, which could have caused extensive damage.

The driller was pressure testing a new feed cylinder for the Sandvik DE130 Diamond Drill. The cylinder was connected to the hydraulic pump to be pressure tested to test for leaks and functionality before installing. The cylinder was pressured up, and passed all of the leak and functionality testing. The pressure gauge on the hydraulic system indicated that the pressure was bleeding off, the pump and power unit were turned off and locked out to prevent re-energization. After the hydraulic gauge reached 0, the driller then began to break the hose fitting between the hydraulic system and the feed cylinder. While wiggling the fitting loose hydraulic fluid that was still under pressure sprayed out towards the drillers face. The driller put his hand up to prevent the fluid from getting in his eyes. After the fluid contacted his hand, which was 4-6" away from the fitting, he felt some mild tingling and a slight burning sensation. The drillers took a few minutes to clean and inspect the hand that was sprayed and decided it wasn't worth risking, so they drove to the 5900 shifter's shack for assistance. Upon reaching the shifters shack the shifters got in touch with the hoistman and the safety department and notified them of the incident. The shifter's brought the diamond drillers immediately to 5100 Silver Shaft station for a ride out. As soon as the drillers reached the surface, the driller with the possible injury was transported immediately to Shoshone Medical Center for further treatment.

The mill run was shutdown at approximately 5:30 PM on the previous shift.   It was assumed that all the reagents were turned off during  the shutdown.  However one reagent was missed during dayshift and that was the Lime to the zinc flash.  This stayed on through the night and this extra lime was makings its way through the sump system to P52, into  the thickener and eventually through WTP 002.  The water treatment operator noticed the pH was higher than usual, which is not much of concern considering this was at the tail end of a mill run and this can happen.  But as it continued to increase he notified the on shift supervisor and the supervisor knew to go check all the lime sources and found one was still on.  He shut off the lime to the Zinc flash and began monitoring pH more frequently to see when it left the system.  He also contacted the mill manager to determine what the high end limits were on pH at WTP 002.  He noted that the pH got at high as 9.6 before it began petering back off.  Our limit at WTP 002 is 10.0 so it was very close to peaking out over our limit.  We were lucky he was able to identify the source before it the level went over the limit.

At approximately 9:30 AM instrument air was lost to the plant, resulting in air actuated valves not being able to properly operate.  This resulted in the underflow valves of both Zn column cells to be  stuck open with no way to operate the air actuated valves.  Both columns started emptying into the basement faster that the floor sump could pump it out.  Booms were placed around the doors at the bottom of the Zn columns to minimize a spill outside of the building, and air was bypassed to the instrument air dryer allowing the valves to be operated again.  In that time approx. 100 gallons of water mixed with Zn column cell overflow leaked around the booms and out the doors.  This spill then reports to the alley, which is graded to the event pond.  While the air was not functioning the feed to the mill was stopped.  It was turned back on 25-30 minutes later and the sand plant remained in operation.  The sand plant, WTP-002, and Pumphouse #4 were unaffected by the air loss, as their feed is separate.

HAZARD RECOGNITION: While shipping Equipment in shaft, and prepping the South side cage to put the long drop down cable inside the cage. We have to unbolt the channel iron on the lip of the bottom deck to be able to lift open the trap door and secure it open. Others have discovered that leaving one bolt loose in the channel iron and removing the rest you can spin the iron so that most of its weight is over the wooden work deck on the fork lift. This limits the risk of dropping the iron. We would sometimes have the operator take the wooden deck and iron away, then move to the next step of lifting the trap door. Usually 2 people would stand on each side of the trap door, one would lift it exposing the open shaft. The assisting toplander asked if we wanted to just leave the wooden deck in-place under the deck as close to the cage rollers as he could so it would minimize the amount of exposed open shaft to the people on the bottom deck securing the door.Worked great, NOW we need to incorporate the wooden deck use while tying off the trailing cable ends. Some loads require a person to reach out into the shaft area further than you probably should. Using the wooden deck for those situations would be best.

During a round at WTP003 a relief supervisor observed an employee dumping a bag of bentonite, a product we use as a seeding material in the water treatment process that interacts with the flocculation process.  It helps to drop more solids out of the overflow, allowing cleaner water to move forward in the filtering stages.  We put this material in the transfer tank which pumps it to the Surge tank.  From time to time we need to dump our underflow to alleviate the solids to Pond 3(soon to be a different destination).  After the dump we return the flow back to the Surge Tanks.  However the Relief Supervisor observed the Operator adding bentonite the transfer tank while he was dumping.  Thus sending the new addition of bentonite directly to the pond.  This has created a loss of process.  This also had the chance of creating an ineffective Water quality in our process with the ability for violation potential.

At approximately 8pm, an employee working night shift reported a strong odor emanating from the hazardous waste shed.  Upon further investigation we discovered that it was a bottle of stench that developed a leak over the weekend.  We also ensured that there was no odor near the property line which would have been a nuisance for an adjacent home owner.

After Vessel #1 completed its normal backwash, the De-entrapment valve located on top of the vessel, failed to seal. This causes water to rush out the top of the vessel when it was automatically put back on-line after the backwash cycle was completed. After taking the #1 Vessel off-line, we discovered that there was a 2"x3"x1/4" piece of white plastic that was jammed and keeping the valve from sealing. The plastic would have had to have been left in the vessel after a recent internal rebuild. No other possible way for it to enter. If no one would have been in the plant at the time water was gushing out the top, the floor sump could have potentially not kept up with the flow and water could have possible left the building.

Employee started pulling muck up the 4 shaft and received a speed reference tracking fault from the bin level press frame.  Operator reset the fault and it cleared with no issues.  About two skips later the operator got the same fault followed by a bang.  Operator stopped pulling muck and took a coworker to investigate.  At that time they discovered that the hydraulic cylinders that control the press frame had dislodged the I-beam that they are attached too from the support beam it sits on.  It sheared off 4 3/4" bolts and moved the beam about 18".  The eyes of the cylinders were cracked.

Type of Incident:  LOSS OF PROCESS
While attempting to pour 12-west we again were leaking too much water in order to do the pour.  The pour was called off early the morning.  The maintenance department had been using silicone to fill the gap between the hopper and the saddle which was not holding properly.  After this pour was called off due to leakage we came up with a new gameplan which would utilize an stronger epoxy to seal the leaking section and stopped using the basic silicone.

Water operator was measuring his reagents just a few minutes into our shift and found the coagulant pump isolated from the tank. The pump had been isolated at some point to do a measure on flow rate and was not valved back properly from the tank to the pump. The operator quickly noticed this issue and valved the reagent back into the normal operating position. He then checked the line for leaks and again did a check to make certain that the pump was working properly and no damage had been done to the line or pump itself. Water operator immediately came and notified me and the mill general foreman of the situation. After he informed me of what he had found we went to the pump and I had him walk me through exactly how it was and what he did to correct the situation.

Loss of Process - Operations planned to start pouring 12-west on the 30th.  The sand plant had not been operated in approximately 3 months.  During that time new barrels were installed in the Schwing pump.  When water was initially sent through the system, operators noticed that the lower U-shaped hopper was not sitting in its saddle like it should.  This caused a very large water leak all along the hopper.  Operators planned to wait and see if the leak would seal itself with sand if the pour was started.  However, when 12-stope called for sand and the operators attempted to switch from water to sand the system program would not initialize to start the emergency belt and BC44.  Operators spent approximately 30 minutes trouble shooting the problems before help was requested from electrical.  Additional electricians were sent up from the underground to assist.  The electricians brought the programming laptop to the sandplant control room and utilized skype to allow a subject matter expert to remote in to the program and force the sequence to restart.  Once that was completed the operators were able to start pouring sand but realized the water leak was too much sand to keep the pour going.  The time was 11:30 which would require all employees on the surface and underground to stay late to get it finished.  The pour was canceled for the day and the pour was rescheduled for the next day which would allow the maintenance department to seal the hopper.

On 9-19-19 at 7:40 pm the mine site experienced a power bump.  The main fans and air compressors tripped out as a result.  Mill supervision began reacting to restart equipment to continue processing ore.  Silas called the night watchman, Dave Rounds, to restart the air compressors because the level and flow controls for each circuit are pneumatic.  Dave returned the call and stated that he had restarted the #1 compressor.  Supervision noted that the air pressure was too low to control the knife gate valves at only 40-50 psi.  Supervision notified Dave Rounds that the air pressure was still low.  Dave confirmed that the #1 compressor was running.  During this time Dave was also trying to reach electricians to start the main underground ventilation fans.  He was able to get in touch with Matt Ulrich who involved the mines' ventilation engineer, Molly McGee, in the fan restart.  Molly was not able to log into Ignition remotely to restart the fans due to an issue with the firewall.  At 10:50 the air pressure to the plant was still too low to control the knife gate valves in the mill.  Dave Rounds called maintenance foreman, Harvey Keim, to ask for help.  Harvey instructed Dave to verify that the #5 air compressor was running.  Dave found that it was off.  Around 11:00 p.m. a second power bump hit and this time the outage lasted about 10 minutes.  After the second power outage mill supervision began an emergency shutdown of the circuits.

ZnSO4 Aro Recirculating pump was not properly shut down.  The pump was dead headed with half of the air left on. While trying to find the main isolation for the fresh water supply to the Slick line bldg to make repairs to some leaking valves inside the bldg. We went to the valve yard to the west of the bldg to look for labeling / isolation valves. There are 3 in ground frost fee isolation valve at a depth of approx 3-4'. We tested 2 of the isolations and tried to bleed the pressure off of the system. The small isolation valve which is in the southeastern most corner of the area is an 1 1/2" - 90 degree turn valve. We isolated it and tested the line pressure to see if it would drop. It did not, we left this valve (In what we thought was the closed position for several minutes and checked with the hoist room and Mill to see if this interrupted any water supply to either area.) We then checked the larger valve inches away from the 1 1/2" next while having the mill monitor flow to the mill. This did not impact the mill flow. We reopened the isolation and noticed water welling up from underground. The 1 1/2" line was apparently already isolated and is either not capped at a dead end U/G or has a broken line that was left isolated. Mill Supervisor found a tag lying on the ground in the area but no longer attached that said DO NOT OPEN THIS VALVE. I called a project engineer to research the drawings to see if we could determine what line had been opened on the maps and to search for the correct isolation that feeds the slickline bldg. The Amount spilled is a difficult estimation because we do not 100% know the source. We assume it is tied into the Mill Fresh water line at some point. But the area maps are not kept up and there have been previous lines discovered due to the age of the site that are not on the maps.

The CoAg Zclear254 pump kicked out to the WTP-002 flocculation tank.  Assumptions that it had kicked out between 1400 hours and 1530 hours as it was manually verified by the operator prior to going to an onsite planned BBQ.  Attached is a photo of a trend that shows the delayed process upset condition.  This is the Units of Turbidity feeding from the 002 clarifier to the Multi Media Filters.  This condition was found and fixed approx.  1530 hours however it takes some time for the upset to come back down.  There was a period of about 3 hours in total where the clarifier overflow to the MMF's was compromised.  At this time there is no reason to suspect that the MMF's were unable to effectively clean the water prior to discharge.  Effluent readings never exceeded Normal ranges.  It was reported first thing in the morning.

The individual had just finished performing repairs to a portion of the lid on KT27 and was releasing the truck and trailer back into service. He forgot to put the lid back down when finished and pulled the truck out of the shop the lid contacting the overhead fall protection then the bay door and door frame header.
FL34 Forklift was not chocked while unattended.
Hydraulic oil spill of 20 liters caused by a 5 gallon spill.
EE was breaking icicles from roof over travelway when an icicle rode down the bar and struck the employee in the upper lip causing a laceration

While trying to level off a load of tails, operator spilled some material and was trying to brush it off of the side rail of the box and hit the access plate with the bucket of the 966 rental loader breaking off 3 bolts on the top right side of KT30.
While staging lime in the lime room the employee was using a forklift, the curtain got caught on the mast, partially tearing down the curtain.

Employee was in the foreman's office and looked down and noticed a large crack through the very old tiles.  Employee has experience with this style of old tile flooring at another company and having contained asbestos.  Because of the disturbance in the tiles because of the large crack and day to day foot traffic the employee reported it to the Environmental Supervisor.
While cleaning out the covered area east of the #2 hoistroom for the new construction taking place - Employee noticed there were several brake bands that "May" have asbestos brake pads.
Wire mesh was hit by mucker bucket during the muck cycle.
Door of buggy swung open while driving forward and caught grill of mill maintenance pickup damaging buggy door hinges so it can't close.  Truck no damage.
Employee was standing at the shifters desk doing paperwork and the snow under their boots melted and left a puddle of water - employee turned to walk and slipped but did not fall.
While opening the right side door window on LR58, finger slipped off of window lock, allowing window to drop 6-8 inches, resulting in a broken window.
In the Garage to the west, by unscrewing a bulb which was "stuck" in its socket, the bulb burst. It cuts off my right index finger.
Hydraulic oil spill of 20 liters caused by a broken hose on the scissor 418.
2 liters of engine oil spilled due to a broken hose on equipment # 408.

While loading trucks with waste, on the 2853 ramp, the loader operator's MX6 alarmed at 40PPM CO. The loading was stopped, main fans were checked, and upon investigation through SCADA, it was determined that the 481 air doors were probably left open temporarily, which drastically reduces air flow on the 2853.

While driving a tour through the mine employee came down the 55 ramp to visit the 6500 L 4 shaft station.  The trucks were hauling waste up the 55 ramp to the 5900 pocket at the same time.  Employee had the block light activated but the truck driver could not see it from the 6500 4 shaft access and turned up the ramp.  Both vehicles came to a stop and the haul truck backed out of the ramp so the Kubota with the tour group could go to the 4 shaft.
Reagent tank leaking to the floor sump.  4" discharge line and coupler were loose and started leaking after employee made a batch of reagent.
Test

Just after attaching the bag on the end of the ship loader snorkel tube, and as the operator started to lift the tube up,  the north hoisting / lowering cable broke apart...  landing on the deck approximately 10' from his location.

While transferring from BT01 to the accommodation ladder ( in windy conditions ) the operator hesitated and as the skiff lowered away from him in the waves, he ended up on his knees on the base of the ladder.

Employee was showing another employee how to move the magnet into position above BC-9.  After words they completed their pre-shift inspection and noticed the power cord for the magnet had not retracted into the reel and was draping over the belt.
When walking to the dry at shift start employee slipped on the snow covered ice.
Sand sand thickener U/F floor sump kicked out.  The building overflowed leaving a sheet of ice in the alleyway.

While soaking the sand filter cloths in water, the excess water runs through the filtrate line to sand thickener.  This water overflows the thickener to P-49, to the underflow floor sump which reports to P-52.  This floor sump kicked out, overflowing the building.  Another employee noticed it before the water had even passed the building, reset the switch gear on the pump an successfully started it.
A report of not water in the porta potty system.  Went to investigate and noted the mechanical room door was open.
Employee was tightening a dwidag with a pipe wrench when the bolt spun loose.
Employee was pulling towards the lucky Friday ramp to service 4213 when his head struck the no parking sign.

After drilling a hole for an 8 foot dwidag employee pulled the steel out of the machine so it doesn't get hung up in the fencing.  Ran steel out - gripped it with the torpedo jaws - reversed rotation and backed away from steel.  Releasing the torpedo jaws the steel sprung away from the rib unexpectedly.
Employee was drilling through shotcrete with a jackleg/  When pulling the step out the leg slipped and the machine fell and employee tripped on a rock and fell.
Bolting lower portion of rib with 4 foot steel.  The steel Shanked and the machine lurched forward.
Spill of 5 liters of antifreeze caused by a broken hose on the T-137 equipment.
As I got off my personal truck at the North parking lot, I set foot on a patch of ice, I fell on the left side.

Employee was draining the water from the dust collector lines and got sprayed with oily water in the face and upper chest.  Employee was wearing safety glasses and did not get any material into eyes or mouth.

Zone 1 miner pulled into m600R3 to clean up for possible retreat slab and noticed paste that should not have been there.  The paste was leaking from m600R5 stope through a diamond drillhole into m660R3.  The paste was about 160ft long by 9ft tall or about 1600tons.

Employee took his gloves off when entering the sandpant to put earplugs in and forgot to put his gloves back on.  The cement scale was stuck during a pour.  He and another employee went up to tap on it to get the cement to drop.  The employee grabbed a hammer head sitting next to the cement scale to give it a tap and pinched his finger against the cement scale when tapping it.
As I got off the truck, I stood behind the inside handle with my right hand, put my right foot on the ground and when I put my left foot down, I was fell because the ground was slippery.
While trying to take out a steel stuck in the wall, I felt a click and a sharp pain in the left forearm (Elbow bend) AT 350 level access.
At my dinner I got up and felt a kick in my left knee. During the morning I worked on snowy slopes.

I was at 410 123, working on the 422 chisel, finishing my hole to install an 8 'swellex, I felt something entered my eye, following or descending the platform to see our foreman who was already there and I told him about it.

Employee needed to work on LCV-200 valve, which had a temporary Xanthate test ran in 3/8" nylon air line in front of the area he needed to work on at about chest height.  Employee lifted temporary tubing stepped under and started work on the valve.  After a few moments he noticed something extremely cold on his upper right thigh.  The tubing had a Tee installed where he had lifted it and the tubing fell off the tee fitting when he let it go behind him after crossing under.  He also started to feel skin irritation at this time

HT-52 Operator opened the A/C cover to check his air filters. He forgot to close the cover and when he backed up the cover caught the rib, causing damage to the cover and box.
Employee was walking to the dry from the silver shaft and slipped and fell on the ice.

Employee was traveling in the EMU, coming down from the #4 shaft hoistroom to pick up another employee.  When he reached 4900 it was louder then usual and there was a little more airflow.  Employee went to investigate and after walking from the chevron to the fuel bay he found that a 1 1/2" air hose that controls the aero pump by the fuel bay had separated from the valve near the back.

Employee was heading home and noticed  a stream of water running out under the West Mill Entrance gate.  The stream continued along the North side of Highway West of Mullan.  Employee stopped and realized it was from snow melt not making it to the even pond in the front of the mill.

Employee filled the water tote for the admin office porta potty system at the mill.  When employee exited the mechanic shop the attempt to stay on the same track going in was made because it was obvious that there was a large iced over "hole" nearby.  Although employee maintained travel on the same track the extra weight from the tote being full caused it to break through ice and the forklift right front wheel dropped down one foot and it was stuck.
Cleaning the cages, the south bell cord froze up.  Got it to pull with a lot of effort .

Ron was troubleshooting an over heating issue on PT17. He confirmed it was not overheating. He then started checking the wiring and sensors on the engine. He attempted to remove the temperature sensor from the engine to test it. At that point he was irritated because he was having difficulty removing the wire connector from the sensor. We were attempting to spot the Ball Mill for the Annual Non Destructive Testing (NDT). We unlocked and initiated a start on the Ball Mill as per the SOP. When we hit the stop button the Ball Mill did not stop immediately. This resulted in us needing to try to spot the Ball Mill again to get it into the correct position for the NDT. After the next restart, the Ball Mill would not shut off at all. We tried to trip the Interlocks for the Lube system after the Stop button failed to shut it down. The Interlocks did not stop it either so we quickly restarted the Lube system. We then tried the "Stop All" button on the panel at the Ball mill and everything (including the lube system again) shut down, but not the Ball Mill. Neil Sholey ran to the MCC room and tried the remote stop button and this also failed to stop the Ball Mill. It finally shut off when Neil switched it from the Manual to the Auto Position (Switching it to the OFF position also failed to stop it). the last option was to switch the live breaker to the off position, which could result in an Arc Flash Hazard.
